name: Red-legged Seriema
description: It’s fairly large, with a slender body, long legs, tail, and neck. Its base color is gray-brown, with a broad black-and-white stripe on the tail. Notable are its red beak, blue eye area, and elongated forehead feathers, which it raises when agitated.
spread_note: From Brazil to Uruguay and northern Argentina
image_alt: Red-legged Seriema, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Length 75–90 cm, including tail 31.5–35 cm; height 85 cm; weight 1.7–2.6 kg
attractions: Seriemas, especially in summer, enjoy perching on branches or stumps, tilting their heads back to 'sing,' marking their territory as a pair. In the South American pampas, their home, this cry carries over 2 km. Seriemas are fascinating birds, closely related to extinct predatory 'terror birds,' known from the film *Journey to the Beginning of Time*. They build twig nests in low trees.
breeding: We’ve kept seriemas continuously since the 1980s and have raised numerous young.
